qas.question: What is the primary cue for migration?
How do birds act in the period before migration?
What does Zugunruhe mean in English?
What do caged birds display that corresponds with migratory direction in nature?
When do caged birds change their preferential direction?

answers.text: the same time their wild conspecifics change course

context: The primary physiological cue for migration are the <a0_0>changes in the day length<a0_0/>. These changes are also related to hormonal changes in the birds. In the period before migration, many birds display <a1_0>higher activity<a1_0/> or Zugunruhe (German: <a2_0>migratory restlessness<a2_0/>), first described by Johann Friedrich Naumann in 1795, as well as physiological changes such as increased fat deposition. The occurrence of Zugunruhe even in cage-raised birds with no environmental cues (e.g. shortening of day and falling temperature) has pointed to the role of circannual endogenous programs in controlling bird migrations. Caged birds display a <a3_0>preferential flight direction<a3_0/> that corresponds with the migratory direction they would take in nature, changing their preferential direction at roughly <a4_0>the same time their wild conspecifics change course<a4_0/>.
